overview_metadata.overview_description: In this lesson, students compare the steps to solve a two-step equation and a two-step inequality. They discover that the solution set remains the same as they perform operations to isolate the variable. Students then solve two-step inequalities and graph their solution sets.

overview_item_data_items: I can develop rules for solving inequalities of the form <math><mi>p</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>q</mi><mo>></mo><mi>r</mi></math> and <math><mi>p</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>q</mi><mo><</mo><mi>r</mi></math>, where <math><mi>p</mi></math>, <math><mi>q</mi></math>, and <math><mi>r</mi></math> are rational numbers.
I can solve two-step inequalities and graph the solution sets on a number line.

I can interpret the graph of a solution set for inequalities of the form <math><mi>p</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>q</mi><mo>></mo><mi>r</math> and <math><mi>p</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>q</mi><mo><</mo><mi>r</mi></math> in the context of a real-world or mathematical problem.

To solve a two-step inequality, apply the same inverse operation steps as you would to solve a two-step equation; however, reverse the inequality symbol when you multiply or divide both sides by a negative value.
The solution set to an inequality informs but is not necessarily the same as the solution set to the problem situation.

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio: Students determine an inequality represented by a solution set graphed on a number line.
Students solve two-step inequalities and graph their solution sets.
Students represent a real-world situation with a two-step inequality and then solve and graph its solution set.

overview_item_data_items: If facilitating this lesson without student devices, no additional materials are needed.
To avoid printing additional materials not included in MATHbook (like Activate activities and Session Quick Checks) project them using the Present button above.
